facts.text: Appellant Nanavati was second in command of Indian Naval Ship Mysore. Married Sylvia in 1949 in England. Three children: boy aged 9 1/2, girl 5 1/2, boy 3 years.
Couple lived in different places due to service exigencies, finally shifted to Bombay. Deceased Ahuja, 34, unmarried businessman in automobiles, resided in Shreyas till 1957, then Jivan Jyot.
In 1956, common friends Agniks introduced Ahuja and sister to Nanavatis. Friendship developed between Ahuja and Sylvia, culminating in illicit intimacy.
On April 27, 1959, Sylvia confessed illicit intimacy with Ahuja to Nanavati.
Enraged, Nanavati went to ship, took semi-automatic revolver and six cartridges on false pretext, loaded it, went to Ahuja's flat, entered bedroom, shot him dead. Surrendered to police.

Accused away with ship April 6-18, 1959. Returned, went to Ahmednagar with wife, brother. Noticed wife strange, unresponsive. On April 27, after lunch, questioned fidelity, she indicated unfaithful, guessed Ahuja.
Decided to settle with Ahuja. Dropped wife and children at cinema. Went to ship for dog medicine, got revolver pretending drive to Ahmednagar alone at night. Put in envelope.

Went to Ahuja's office, not there, then flat. Servant opened, went to bedroom, shut door. Asked if marry Sylvia and care for children. Ahuja retorted 'Am I to marry every woman I sleep with?'. Enraged, threatened to thrash. Ahuja moved for envelope, struggle, two shots accidental.
Accused charged under s.302 and s.304 Part I IPC, tried by Sessions Judge Greater Bombay with special jury.
Jury verdict not guilty by 8:1 under both sections.
Sessions Judge disagreed, as majority verdict such that no reasonable body could bring it on evidence. Submitted under s.307 CrPC to Bombay High Court.
Bombay HC division bench (Shelat and Naik JJ) held guilty under s.302 IPC, sentenced to rigorous life imprisonment. Shelat J found misdirections, reviewed evidence. Naik J found verdict unreasonable.
Both HC judges agreed no case to reduce to culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether reference under s.307 CrPC by Sessions Judge competent only on perusal of order, without considering evidence.
Whether High Court under s.307 CrPC has power to set aside jury verdict on ground of misdirections in charge.
Whether there were misdirections in Sessions Judge's charge to jury.
Whether jury verdict perverse, such that no reasonable body could arrive at it.
Whether accused acted under grave and sudden provocation, reducing offence to culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s.307 CrPC, HC decides competency of reference only on perusal of referring order, no jurisdiction to consider evidence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.307 CrPC; Ramanugrah Singh v. King Emperor

petitioner_arguments.text: HC under s.307 has no power to set aside jury verdict on misdirections.
No misdirections in charge; charge fair to both sides.
Jury verdict not perverse; reasonable body could arrive at it. Alternatively, grave and sudden provocation.

respondent_arguments.text: HC can consider entire evidence under s.307(3) CrPC after finding reference competent.
Misdirections vitiated verdict; no grave sudden provocation.

court_reasoning.text: Reference competent if Sessions Judge disagrees with jury and clearly opines no reasonable body could reach verdict, recording grounds. HC then considers entire evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two conditions for reference satisfied ex facie.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.307(3) CrPC, HC exercises appellate-like powers, considers entire evidence, gives due weight to Judge and jury opinions. Can interfere if misdirections or verdict unreasonable/perverse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wider jurisdiction than appeal under s.418 CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: Grave misdirections/omissions: No reference to s.105 Evidence Act presumption; failed to explain s.80 IPC not applicable or burden on accused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mixed ingredients of offence and exception; abdicated function to jury.

court_reasoning.text: Misdirection on grave sudden provocation: Left entirely to jury as fact, though question of law whether wife's confession amounts to provocation by deceased.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error in telling jury entire question one of fact.

court_reasoning.text: Told jury case rests on circumstantial evidence requiring stringent proof, despite direct extra-judicial confession to Puransingh.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confused jury on approach to evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Omission to refer to three letters by Sylvia showing state of mind re marriage with Ahuja.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Important for credibility of Sylvia and Nanavati evidence.

court_reasoning.text: s.105 Evidence Act: Burden on accused to rebut presumption of absence of general exceptions like s.80 IPC; prosecution still proves ingredients of offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No conflict with general burden on prosecution.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide if provocation question purely fact under Expl.1 Exc.1 s.300 IPC, as AG concedes no misdirection there.
Verdict vitiated by misdirections; HC right to review evidence and convict.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Perverse and contrary to weight of evidence.

holdings.text: Reference under s.307 CrPC competent if two conditions satisfied ex facie; HC then considers entire evidence.
HC under s.307(3) CrPC can set aside jury verdict for misdirections or if unreasonable/perverse.
Multiple grave misdirections/omissions in charge vitiated verdict.
Jury verdict perverse; no reduction to culpable homicide on provocation.

precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of s.307 CrPC; ends of justice mean verdict no reasonable body could reach.

precedents_cited.case_name: Akhlakali Hayatalli v. The State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide power under s.307 CrPC; misdirections can vitiate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ratan Rai v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: HC must consider entire evidence and charge under s.307.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sashi Mohan Debnath v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Sessions Judge must submit whole case under s.307(2).
Misdirection under s.537 CrPC; no weight to erroneous verdict.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mushtak Hussein v. The State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Misdirection must occasion failure of justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Nagindra Bala Mitra v. Sunil Chandra Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Restates test for misdirection vitiating verdict.

precedents_cited.case_name: Holmes v. Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents_cited.relevance: English law on provocation; judge rules if evidence supports.

precedents_cited.case_name: Woolmington v. Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution proves guilt; accused raises doubt.
s.106 Evidence not casting burden to disprove crime.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Murder charge; accident exception; provocation reducing to culpable homicide.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference on jury disagreement; jury trial procedure; appeals limited to law in jury cases.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Burden on accused for general exceptions; presumption of absence.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected appellant's contentions on procedural points under s.307 CrPC, upheld finding of grave misdirections vitiating jury verdict, confirmed conviction under s.302 IPC and life imprisonment by Bombay High Court.

key_quotes.text: The High Court shall give weight to the verdict of the jury but the weight to be given to a verdict depends upon many circumstances-it may be one that no reasonable body of persons could come to it may be a perverse verdict it may be a divided verdict
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains due weight under s.307(3) CrPC.

key_quotes.text: In India, as it is in England, there is a presumption of innocence in favour of the accused as a general rule, and it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the guilt of the accused
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies burden of proof alongside s.105 Evidence Act.

key_quotes.text: Unless therefore it is established in a case that there has been a serious misdirection by the judge in charging the jury which has occasioned a failure of justice and has misled the jury in giving its verdict, the verdict of the jury cannot be set aside.
key_quotes.speaker: court
